gem.description: From prehistory to the Greco-Roman era - experience the world's largest archaeological museum

history.description: A journey through time from the dawn of Egyptian civilization to the modern era

location.description: Just 2 km from the Giza Pyramids with direct views of the monuments

history.title: Living History
history.description: 7000 years of Egyptian civilization in 50 interactive galleries

sustainable.title: Sustainable Design
sustainable.description: Solar panels, natural lighting, and eco-friendly systems

night.title: Night Experience
night.description: Dramatic lighting and light shows during evening hours

highlights.title: Iconic Highlights
highlights.subtitle: Discover the most extraordinary treasures awaiting you at the Grand Egyptian Museum

mask.title: Tutankhamun's Mask
mask.description: The iconic golden mask of the boy king, crafted from 11kg of pure gold

obelisk.title: The Hanging Obelisk
obelisk.description: An engineering marvel - an 11-meter obelisk suspended in mid-air

staircase.title: The Grand Staircase
staircase.description: 87 statues of pharaohs and deities in a procession through time

videoShowcase.title: Virtual Tour
videoShowcase.subtitle: Explore the museum from your home with our interactive virtual tour

newsletter.title: Join Our Newsletter
newsletter.subtitle: Be the first to know about opening dates, special exhibitions, and exclusive events

artifacts.title: Featured Masterpieces
artifacts.subtitle: Explore the most extraordinary artifacts from 7,000 years of Egyptian civilization

tutMask.title: Tutankhamun's Golden Mask
tutMask.description: The most iconic symbol of ancient Egypt - a masterpiece of royal craftsmanship featuring inlaid lapis lazuli, carnelian, and colored glass. The double crown represents the pharaoh's rule over Upper and Lower Egypt.

throne.title: Tutankhamun's Throne
throne.description: An exquisite example of ancient Egyptian royal furniture, featuring intricate inlays of semi-precious stones. The backrest depicts the pharaoh with his wife Ankhesenamun in a scene of intimate domestic life.

chariot.title: Royal War Chariot
chariot.details: Fully functional, used for hunting and warfare
chariot.description: An expertly crafted wheeled vehicle demonstrating advanced metallurgical skills. The chariot features gilded bronze decorative elements and leather fittings, revealing the sophistication of ancient Egyptian transportation.

necklace.title: Royal Pectoral Necklace
necklace.description: An elaborate broad collar worn by pharaohs, adorned with symbolic elements representing gods and royal protection. Each stone was carefully selected and positioned according to ancient beliefs.

sarcophagus.title: Nested Sarcophagi
sarcophagus.description: A magnificent set of three coffins, each crafted from rare wood materials. The innermost coffin is made almost entirely of solid gold and weighs over 100 kg, showcasing the immense wealth of the pharaoh.

kohl.title: Ivory Cosmetic Containers
kohl.description: Intricately carved cosmetic containers revealing the sophistication of ancient Egyptian beauty practices. These items show that the pharaoh understood and valued personal grooming and appearance.

historicalTimeline.title: 7,000 Years of Egyptian History
historicalTimeline.subtitle: From the earliest settlements to the Greco-Roman era

predynastic.description: The earliest period of human settlement along the Nile Valley. Nomadic hunter-gatherers gradually transitioned to agricultural communities, establishing the foundations of Egyptian civilization.
predynastic.achievements: Development of agriculture, pottery, and early writing systems

oldKingdom.description: The age of pyramid building and centralized pharaonic power. This era saw the construction of the Great Pyramids of Giza and the establishment of Egyptian artistic and architectural standards.
oldKingdom.achievements: Construction of the greatest monuments of the ancient world at Giza

middleKingdom.description: A period of cultural renaissance and stability. Art, literature, and science flourished, while Egypt extended its influence through military campaigns and trade.
middleKingdom.achievements: Classical period of Egyptian art and literature; works of this era are considered timeless masterpieces

newKingdom.description: Egypt's most powerful and prosperous era. This period witnessed the reign of legendary pharaohs including Hatshepsut, Thutmose III, and Ramesses II, whose monuments dominated the landscape.
newKingdom.achievements: Height of Egyptian power and the construction of the most famous temples and monuments

ptolemaicGrecoRoman.description: After Alexander the Great's conquest, Greek and Roman cultures merged with Egyptian traditions. The Ptolemaic dynasty ruled Egypt, culminating with Cleopatra VII.
ptolemaicGrecoRoman.achievements: The Fayum mummy portraits represent the finest achievements of this period - a unique blend of Egyptian and Greco-Roman artistic traditions

architecture.title: Architectural Masterpiece
architecture.subtitle: A modern sanctuary for ancient treasures

hangingObelisk.title: The Hanging Obelisk
hangingObelisk.description: An engineering marvel that greets every visitor upon entry. This massive granite obelisk appears to float in mid-air above the atrium floor, accomplishing what ancient Egyptians could only dream of - defying gravity while honoring their architectural legacy.

grandStaircase.title: The Grand Staircase
grandStaircase.description: A breathtaking architectural element stretching 35 meters tall, featuring statues of all the great pharaohs and deities in chronological order. Walking up this staircase is a journey through Egypt's entire history.

ramasesesColossus.title: Ramesses II Colossus
ramasesesColossus.description: A colossal statue of Ramesses II, one of Egypt's greatest pharaohs, welcomes visitors as they enter the museum. This modern recreation captures the grandeur of the original Karnak temples.

alabasterFacade.title: Translucent Alabaster Facade
alabasterFacade.description: The museum's distinctive facade features panels of fine alabaster - the same material used in ancient Egyptian temples. These panels filter sunlight naturally, creating an ethereal atmosphere while maintaining optimal lighting for artifact preservation.

triangularDesign.title: Pyramid-Inspired Triangular Design
triangularDesign.view: Direct sightline to the Great Pyramids
triangularDesign.description: The museum's overall triangular footprint echoes the pyramids visible just 2 kilometers away, creating a visual bridge between the ancient and modern achievements of Egyptian civilization.

atrium.title: The Grand Atrium
atrium.visitors: Can view hanging obelisk from all heights
atrium.description: A soaring central space that serves as the heart of the museum, allowing visitors to experience the hanging obelisk from multiple perspectives and levels, creating an unparalleled sense of scale and wonder.

visitorExperience.title: Make the Most of Your Visit
visitorExperience.subtitle: Expert tips for an unforgettable journey through ancient Egypt

tips.heading: Best Days to Visit
tips.details: Weekday mornings (Tuesday-Thursday, 9:00-11:00 AM) are least crowded. First hours after opening provide the best lighting and smallest crowds.

tips.heading: Recommended Duration
tips.details: Allow 4-5 hours for a thorough exploration of main galleries. Full day (8+ hours) for enthusiasts wanting to experience every detail.

tips.heading: Seasonal Considerations
tips.details: October to April offers pleasant weather. Avoid peak summer (June-August) when temperatures exceed 35Â°C.

tips.heading: Recommended Route
tips.details: Start with Prehistoric Egypt on the ground level, then ascend chronologically through the dynasties. This creates a natural narrative flow through 7,000 years.

tips.heading: Highlight Priority Stops
tips.details: Must-see: Tutankhamun galleries (2-3 hours), The Grand Staircase, The Hanging Obelisk, Ramesses II galleries.

tips.heading: Audio Guide Enhancement
tips.details: Available in 10 languages. Provides 5-15 minute commentaries on key artifacts. Highly recommended for deep understanding.

tips.heading: Wear Comfortable Shoes
tips.details: Plan for 6-10 km of walking depending on your route. Supportive footwear is essential for all-day exploring.

tips.heading: Bring Essentials
tips.details: Water bottle (refill stations available), portable charger, light jacket (air conditioning can be cool), sunglasses for outdoor arrival/departure area.

tips.heading: Pace Yourself
tips.details: Take breaks in cafes on each level. The museum's design allows for strategic rest stops with views.

tips.heading: Guided Tours
tips.details: Expert-led 2-hour tours provide context and fascinating details. Photography tours available for enthusiasts.

tips.heading: Interactive Displays
tips.details: Digital reconstructions show how artifacts were used. Augmented Reality experiences bring ancient scenes to life.

tips.heading: Conservation Center
tips.details: Witness live restoration work. Understand the science and dedication required to preserve these treasures for future generations.

tips.heading: Photography Allowed
tips.details: Permitted in most galleries without flash. Professional photography permits available for DSLR and mirrorless cameras.

tips.heading: Best Photo Spots
tips.details: Hang Obelisk from all levels, Grand Staircase chambers, Tutankhamun galleries, Ramesses II corridors.

tips.heading: Lighting Tips
tips.details: Natural light is best in morning hours. Late afternoon provides dramatic shadows in key galleries.

tips.heading: Children's Museum
tips.details: Dedicated interactive museum for ages 5-12. Hands-on activities, mummy wrapping, and pyramid building workshops.

tips.heading: Family-Friendly Route
tips.details: Focus on visually impressive items first (colorful items, large statues). Break sessions with activities in children's museum.

tips.heading: Educational Value
tips.details: Free family worksheets available at entrance. Scavenger hunt activities engage children while learning.

footer.description: The world's largest archaeological museum dedicated to a single civilization

hero.label: Museum Story
hero.title: Where Ancient Meets Modern
hero.description: The Grand Egyptian Museum stands as a testament to human achievement - a bridge between the ancient world and contemporary innovation, dedicated to preserving and sharing the rich tapestry of Egyptian civilization.

architecture.label: Architecture
architecture.title: Designed to Inspire
architecture.p1: The museum's architecture is a dialogue between past and present. The triangular facade echoes the pyramids of Giza, while the translucent alabaster facade filters natural light, creating an ethereal atmosphere within.
architecture.p2: Designed by the Irish firm Heneghan Peng Architects, the building spans 480,000 square meters and includes exhibition halls, conservation centers, a children's museum, and extensive educational facilities.

visionBegins.title: The Vision Begins
visionBegins.description: The Egyptian government announces the ambitious project to build the world's largest archaeological museum.

foundationLaid.title: Foundation Laid
foundationLaid.description: Construction begins on the 480,000 square meter site, just 2 kilometers from the Giza Pyramids.

challenges.title: Challenges & Resilience
challenges.description: Despite political and economic challenges, work continues with international support and dedication.

staircase.title: Grand Staircase Unveiled
staircase.description: The iconic grand staircase is completed, featuring 87 statues of pharaohs and deities.

tutCollection.title: Tutankhamun Collection
tutCollection.description: All 5,398 artifacts from King Tut's tomb are moved to the museum for the first time in history.

opening.title: Grand Opening
opening.description: The museum opens its doors, welcoming visitors to experience 7,000 years of Egyptian civilization.

sustainable.title: Sustainable Design
sustainable.description: The museum incorporates solar panels, rainwater harvesting, and energy-efficient systems to minimize its environmental footprint.

conservation.title: State-of-the-Art Conservation
conservation.description: Advanced laboratories and climate-controlled environments ensure the preservation of delicate artifacts for future generations.

interactive.title: Interactive Technology
interactive.description: Digital displays, augmented reality experiences, and immersive installations bring ancient history to life.

education.title: Educational Programs
education.description: Workshops, lectures, and guided tours designed for all ages, fostering a deeper understanding of Egyptian heritage.

cta.title: Ready to Experience History?
cta.text: Plan your visit to the Grand Egyptian Museum and embark on a journey through 7,000 years of civilization.

hero.label: Museum Journeys
hero.title: A Living Narrative of Egyptian Civilization
hero.description: Move through 50 curated galleries that connect artifacts, architecture, and storytelling into one continuous museum journey across 7,000 years.

featured.label: Signature Experience
featured.title: Tutankhamun: The Complete Collection
featured.description: For the first time in history, all 5,398 artifacts from King Tutankhamun's tomb are displayed together in a single, immersive experience. Walk through the life, death, and afterlife of the boy king who captured the world's imagination.
featured.descriptionExtended: The galleries are arranged as a narrative journey, from courtly life and ritual to burial traditions and rediscovery. Multimedia stations and carefully lit displays reveal the craftsmanship behind each object, from gold inlay to carved cedar.
highlights: Contextual storytelling from life to afterlife
Object-level details on materials and techniques

goldenThrone.caption: Ceremonial throne with intricate royal iconography

tutChariot.caption: One of the king's chariots preserved with remarkable detail

egyptianJewelry.caption: Fine royal jewelry illustrating symbolic protection motifs

tutankhamun.title: Tutankhamun Galleries
tutankhamun.subtitle: The Complete Collection
tutankhamun.description: For the first time in history, all 5,398 artifacts from King Tutankhamun's tomb are displayed together. Journey through the boy king's life, death, and afterlife with his legendary golden mask, throne, chariots, and jewelry.
tutankhamun.story: These galleries unfold in thematic chapters that explain how each object functioned in royal life, ritual performance, and funerary belief.
quickFacts: Complete collection reunited for the first time
Displays include ceremonial, military, and domestic objects
Interpretive media links each artifact to its original context

prehistoric.title: Prehistoric Egypt
prehistoric.subtitle: The Dawn of Civilization
prehistoric.description: Explore Egypt before the pharaohs, from the earliest human settlements along the Nile to the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt. Discover ancient tools, pottery, and the foundations of Egyptian culture.
prehistoric.story: Material traces from villages, workshops, and burials reveal how social structure, craft specialization, and symbolic expression emerged over millennia.
quickFacts: Chronological layout from early Nile communities to late Predynastic Egypt
Comparative displays show evolving pottery and stone-tool traditions
Panels explain the cultural foundations of early kingship

oldKingdom.title: The Old Kingdom
oldKingdom.subtitle: Age of the Pyramid Builders
oldKingdom.description: Step into the era when Egypt built its greatest monuments. Marvel at statues of pharaohs, learn about the construction of the pyramids, and discover the daily life of ancient Egyptians.
oldKingdom.story: Monumental sculpture and tomb reliefs are paired with interpretive diagrams to explain administration, labor, and ideology during the pyramid age.
quickFacts: Focus on elite and non-elite life in the Memphite region
Stone-working techniques presented with close-up visual references
Burial inscriptions contextualized with religious beliefs

newKingdom.title: The New Kingdom
newKingdom.subtitle: Egypt's Golden Age
newKingdom.description: Experience the height of Egyptian power and prosperity. From Hatshepsut to Ramesses II, explore the lives of legendary pharaohs and the magnificent artifacts they left behind.
newKingdom.story: Royal monuments, temple programs, and elite burials illustrate how imperial ambition, diplomacy, and religious spectacle shaped the period.
quickFacts: Highlights include major state cult imagery and royal portraiture
Cross-references connect objects to major archaeological sites

grecoRoman.title: Greco-Roman Egypt
grecoRoman.subtitle: Where Cultures Converge
grecoRoman.description: Discover the fascinating period when Egyptian traditions blended with Greek and Roman influences. See the famous Fayum mummy portraits and learn about the Ptolemaic dynasty.
grecoRoman.story: Bilingual texts, painted portraits, and hybrid iconography show how local traditions adapted under Mediterranean political and artistic influence.
quickFacts: Tracks artistic transition from Ptolemaic to Roman rule
Portrait panels reveal changing funerary representation
Numismatic and textile displays emphasize cultural exchange

conservation.title: Conservation Center
conservation.subtitle: Preserving the Past
conservation.description: Go behind the scenes and witness the meticulous work of conservators restoring ancient artifacts. Interactive displays explain the science behind preservation.
conservation.story: The center presents conservation as an ongoing scientific process, from condition assessment and imaging to stabilization and preventive care.
quickFacts: Explains laboratory workflows used in large museum projects
Demonstrates non-invasive imaging and analysis methods
Shows how climate control protects fragile surfaces

details.label: Exhibition Insights
details.title: Context, Craft, and Discovery
details.intro: Beyond labels and dates, this section expands the stories behind the objects, the curatorial choices, and the spatial design of the exhibition route.
details.paragraph1: Each gallery is organized to balance scholarly depth and visitor readability. Introductory panels establish historical context, while focused object labels explain materials, techniques, and symbolic meanings.
details.paragraph2: Lighting and spatial sequencing are designed to guide attention without overwhelming the viewer. Large anchor objects create orientation points, and adjacent cases provide thematic continuity.
details.paragraph3: The result is a layered experience: visitors can follow the narrative quickly, or slow down and examine object-level detail through extended captions and visual aids.
keyPoints: Narrative flow follows chronology and thematic transitions between halls.
Key objects are paired with focused interpretation for deeper understanding.
Visual wayfinding helps visitors navigate long routes with minimal friction.
Conservation notes highlight how preservation decisions shape display.

atrium.title: Arrival in the Grand Atrium
atrium.text: The atrium establishes scale, orientation, and atmosphere before visitors enter the chronological galleries.
atrium.imageAlt: Grand atrium of the exhibition complex

staircase.title: The Grand Staircase Sequence
staircase.text: A sculptural procession of royal monuments builds a visual bridge between major historical periods.

goldenThrone.title: Royal Craftsmanship in Focus
goldenThrone.text: Gold surfaces, fine inlays, and iconographic scenes reveal the technical mastery of court workshops.
goldenThrone.imageAlt: Golden throne displayed in museum gallery

mummyCase.title: Funerary Design and Belief
mummyCase.text: Nested coffins and decorated cases illustrate how material, text, and image combined in funerary practice.
mummyCase.imageAlt: Decorated mummy case in exhibition hall

experience.label: Visit In Different Styles
experience.title: Choose Your Museum Route
experience.intro: Pick the route that matches your pace and interests. Each style offers a different way to understand the museum, from a fast highlights pass to a research-focused deep dive.

express.title: Highlights In 90 Minutes
express.summary: A concise route for visitors with limited time who still want to experience the museum's strongest visual and historical moments.
express.suitableFor: Best for: First-time visitors and short schedules

classic.title: The Essential Museum Experience
classic.summary: A balanced route that combines chronological context, iconic objects, and practical rest points for a complete yet comfortable visit.
classic.suitableFor: Best for: Most visitors and family groups

deepDive.title: Deep Reading Of The Collection
deepDive.summary: A detail-rich route for history enthusiasts who want more interpretation, cross-period comparisons, and conservation-focused context.
deepDive.suitableFor: Best for: Researchers, enthusiasts, and repeat visits

tickets.q: Do I need to book tickets in advance?
tickets.a: Advance booking is strongly recommended for weekends and holidays. Pre-booked tickets also make entry smoother during peak hours.

family.q: Is this route suitable for families with children?
family.a: Yes. The balanced route is family-friendly, with natural pause points, open circulation zones, and shorter thematic clusters.

accessibility.q: Can visitors with mobility needs complete the full experience?
accessibility.a: Yes. Elevators, ramps, and accessible pathways connect major galleries. Ask staff for the most convenient route at entry.

services.q: Where can I find rest areas and visitor services?
services.a: Services are distributed across major nodes of the museum route, including seating zones, cafes, information counters, and restrooms.

route.title: Recommended Route
route.text: Start with Prehistoric Egypt and follow the chronological path through the galleries for the most immersive experience.

audio.title: Audio Guides
audio.text: Available in 10 languages, our audio guides provide in-depth commentary on key artifacts and exhibitions.

timing.title: Best Times to Visit
timing.text: Weekday mornings are less crowded. Allow at least 4-5 hours to explore the main galleries thoroughly.

photo.title: Photography
photo.text: Photography is permitted in most galleries without flash. Special exhibitions may have restrictions.

cta.title: Begin Your Journey Through History
cta.text: Book your tickets now and experience 7,000 years of Egyptian civilization in the world's largest archaeological museum.

hero.label: Plan Your Visit
hero.title: Everything You Need to Know
hero.description: Prepare for your journey through 7,000 years of Egyptian civilization. Find information on tickets, hours, directions, and more.

hours.title: Opening Hours
hours.notice: Last entry is 2 hours before closing. Galleries begin closing 30 minutes before the museum closes.

car.title: By Car
car.description: The museum is located on the Alexandria Desert Road, just 2 km from the Giza Pyramids. Free parking is available for visitors.

bus.title: By Bus
bus.description: Public buses 355 and 357 run from Tahrir Square to the museum. The journey takes approximately 45 minutes.

metro.title: By Metro
metro.description: Take Line 2 to Giza Station, then a short taxi ride or bus to the museum. Total journey time is about 1 hour.

map.title: Interactive Museum Map
map.subtitle: Select a route style, then click any zone to view corridor guidance, nearby services, and movement details.
map.a11yLabel: Interactive interior route map for the museum

floorDescriptions.ground: Primary orientation, entry validation, and major transition axes.
floorDescriptions.upper: Main royal and chronological galleries with high artifact density.
floorDescriptions.lower: Conservation-linked educational corridors and calmer movement.

arrival.title: Arrival Plaza
arrival.description: Primary entry zone with ticket validation, information points, and orientation displays before entering the main circulation axis.
corridors: Wide central corridor designed for first-contact wayfinding.
Direct visual connection to atrium navigation to reduce confusion.
Queue spillover managed through side holding lanes.
tips: Complete orientation before moving into the atrium node.
Use side lanes if entry queues become dense.
Keep ticket and map access ready at this stage.
arrival.imageAlt: Museum arrival plaza and entrance zone

atrium.title: Grand Atrium Node
atrium.description: Main orientation node where visitors choose between chronological galleries, staircase ascent, and service corridors.
corridors: Radial corridors branch toward major galleries and vertical movement.
Clear sightlines support quick orientation for first-time visitors.
Digital signage updates route density in real time.
tips: If visiting with family, pause here before choosing your branch.
Use digital signs to compare crowd levels across routes.
This is the best point to switch from quick to extended route.

staircase.title: Grand Staircase Spine
staircase.description: Vertical transition corridor linking major narrative levels with staged sculpture views and pause platforms.
corridors: Dual-flow movement path separates ascent and descent directionally.
Rest niches reduce bottlenecks during photo-heavy stops.
Alternative elevator path mirrors the same destination logic.
tips: Keep right on ascent during peak movement windows.
Use pause niches for photos instead of central flow lanes.
Switch to lift route if your group needs lower pace.

tutankhamun.title: Tutankhamun Galleries
tutankhamun.description: High-demand galleries with controlled sequencing and thematic transitions from royal life to funerary context.
corridors: One-way sequence minimizes backtracking in dense areas.
Buffer corridors handle queue pressure near signature objects.
Exit links reconnect smoothly to broader upper-level circulation.
tips: Follow one-way signage for the smoothest artifact progression.
Avoid pausing in narrow neck points near signature displays.
Use buffer corridor pauses for deeper reading of object labels.

newKingdom.title: New Kingdom Corridor Cluster
newKingdom.description: Connected halls with wider transitional corridors to distribute movement between major royal collections.
corridors: Cross-links allow flexible pacing without losing chronology.
Directional markers separate thematic branches clearly.
Intermediate service pockets support longer stays.
tips: Use branch markers to maintain chronology while exploring side galleries.
Choose cross-links when one branch becomes crowded.
Plan a short break before transitioning toward later periods.

grecoRoman.title: Greco-Roman Wing
grecoRoman.description: Later-period galleries with calmer circulation and clear loops back toward exits and secondary service areas.
corridors: Looped corridor geometry supports non-linear exploration.
Short branch corridors connect thematic sub-collections.
Return route to atrium is marked through consistent node coding.
tips: Use loop geometry to revisit any case without losing direction.
Branch corridors are ideal for quieter close viewing.
Node coding here provides one of the easiest return paths.

conservation.title: Conservation Access Corridor
conservation.description: Educational corridor near conservation spaces with slower visitor flow and interpretive stops about preservation processes.
corridors: Wider observation pockets allow stops without blocking circulation.
Low-density route works well for accessible pacing.
Direct return path reconnects to main hall backbone.
tips: Take advantage of low density for detailed interpretive reading.
Use this route if your group prefers slower, quieter navigation.
Rejoin the main spine through the marked connector corridor.

corridors.title: Corridor Intelligence
corridors.intro: Use these practical movement rules to navigate the museum smoothly, avoid congestion, and choose the right route rhythm for your group.

flow.title: Flow Dynamics
flow.description: Major movement peaks usually occur at transition nodes. Choose staggered entry timing for faster progression.

navigation.title: Wayfinding Logic
navigation.description: Follow node-based orientation: each main hub connects clearly to 2-3 major destinations with directional consistency.

accessibility.title: Inclusive Paths
accessibility.description: Accessible alternatives mirror core routes and maintain narrative continuity with minimal detours.

services.title: Service Coverage
services.description: Amenities are distributed near key nodes so visitors can pause, recover, and continue without leaving the main route.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.text: The Grand Egyptian Museum is committed to providing an inclusive experience for all visitors. Our facilities and services ensure everyone can enjoy the wonders of ancient Egypt.

tips.label: Helpful Tips
tips.title: Make the Most of Your Visit

bestTime.title: Best Time to Visit
bestTime.description: Weekday mornings are less crowded. Allow at least 4-5 hours for the main galleries.

bring.title: What to Bring
bring.description: Comfortable walking shoes, water bottle, and a light jacket (air conditioning can be cool).

photo.title: Photography
photo.description: Allowed in most areas without flash. Tripods and professional equipment require permits.

food.title: Food & Drink
food.description: Several cafes and restaurants are available inside. Outside food is not permitted in galleries.

hero.label: Tickets
hero.title: Book Your Visit
hero.description: Secure your entry to the world's largest archaeological museum. Choose your date, time, and ticket options.

timedEntry.title: Timed Entry
timedEntry.text: Please arrive within your selected time slot. Entry is guaranteed for 30 minutes after your selected time.

groupBookings.title: Group Bookings
groupBookings.text: For groups of 10 or more, enjoy discounted rates and optional guided tours. Contact us for arrangements.

cancellation.title: Free Cancellation
cancellation.text: Full refund available up to 24 hours before your visit. Reschedule anytime at no extra cost.

hero.label: The Collection
hero.title: 100,000 Artifacts
hero.description: Explore the world's largest collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts, including the complete treasures of Tutankhamun, displayed together for the first time in history.
